name: Tech Visionaries
description: Words of wisdom from the pioneers who shaped our digital world.
author: Quips Editorial

quotes.content: Stay hungry, stay foolish.
quotes.source: The Whole Earth Catalog, back cover (1974)
quotes.notes: Final issue of The Whole Earth Catalog. Steve Jobs quoted this in his 2005 Stanford commencement speech, greatly popularizing it.

quotes.content: The best way to predict the future is to invent it.
quotes.notes: Said during a meeting at Xerox PARC where Kay worked on early personal computing concepts. Verified through multiple accounts of PARC history.

quotes.content: Move fast and break things. Unless you are breaking stuff, you are not moving fast enough.
quotes.notes: Early Facebook motto, later changed to 'Move fast with stable infrastructure' in 2014. Reflects the startup culture of rapid iteration.

quotes.content: Your most unhappy customers are your greatest source of learning.
quotes.notes: From Gates' book on digital business transformation. Emphasizes the value of customer feedback in product development.

quotes.content: The people who are crazy enough to think they can change the world are the ones who do.
quotes.notes: From Apple's iconic 'Think Different' ad campaign, narrated by Richard Dreyfuss. Often attributed to Steve Jobs but written by Rob Siltanen and TBWA\Chiat\Day.

quotes.content: Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.
quotes.notes: Clarke's Third Law from his essay collection. The definitive version appeared in the 1973 revision.

quotes.content: The computer was born to solve problems that did not exist before.
quotes.notes: Commonly attributed to Gates. Reflects the paradox of technology creating new needs while solving old ones.

quotes.content: When something is important enough, you do it even if the odds are not in your favor.
quotes.notes: From a CBS 60 Minutes interview about SpaceX and Tesla. Musk discussed taking risks despite high probability of failure.

quotes.content: Innovation distinguishes between a leader and a follower.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Jobs. Consistent with Apple's emphasis on innovation over imitation during his second tenure.

quotes.content: The Internet is becoming the town square for the global village of tomorrow.
quotes.notes: From Gates' book predicting the future of technology. Written before the mainstream adoption of the World Wide Web.

quotes.content: Don't be evil.
quotes.notes: Former Google corporate motto, attributed to Paul Buchheit and Amit Patel. Changed to 'Do the right thing' when Alphabet was formed in 2015.

quotes.content: It's really hard to design products by focus groups. A lot of times, people don't know what they want until you show it to them.
quotes.notes: From a BusinessWeek interview discussing Apple's design philosophy. Jobs advocated for visionary product design over market research.

quotes.content: The future is already here â€” it's just not very evenly distributed.
quotes.notes: From an NPR 'Fresh Air' interview. Gibson, author of Neuromancer, coined the term 'cyberspace.'

quotes.content: We tend to overestimate the effect of a technology in the short run and underestimate the effect in the long run.
quotes.notes: Known as Amara's Law. Roy Amara was president of the Institute for the Future. Describes the 'hype cycle' phenomenon.

quotes.content: I think it is possible for ordinary people to choose to be extraordinary.
quotes.notes: Musk has expressed this sentiment in multiple interviews about human potential and ambition.

quotes.content: Technology is a useful servant but a dangerous master.
quotes.notes: From Lange's Nobel lecture on internationalism. Though from 1921, it remains relevant to modern technology discussions.

quotes.content: In the future, everyone will be world-famous for 15 minutes.
quotes.notes: From a 1968 exhibition catalog. Prophetically describes today's social media and viral content culture.

quotes.content: Simple can be harder than complex: You have to work hard to get your thinking clean to make it simple.
quotes.notes: From the same BusinessWeek interview. Describes Apple's design philosophy of elegant simplicity.

quotes.content: The most dangerous phrase in the language is 'We've always done it this way.'
quotes.notes: Attributed to pioneering computer scientist Grace Hopper. Reflects her advocacy for innovation in computing.

quotes.content: Information is power. But like all power, there are those who want to keep it for themselves.
quotes.notes: From Swartz's manifesto advocating for open access to academic research. Swartz was a digital rights activist and programmer.

quotes.content: Privacy is dead, and social media holds the smoking gun.
quotes.notes: From Mashable founder Pete Cashmore's commentary on the changing nature of privacy in the social media age.

quotes.content: The biggest risk is not taking any risk. In a world that's changing really quickly, the only strategy that is guaranteed to fail is not taking risks.
quotes.notes: From Zuckerberg's talk at Y Combinator. Advocates for calculated risk-taking in entrepreneurship.

quotes.content: Hardware: the parts of a computer that can be kicked.
quotes.notes: Humorous definition often shared in tech circles. Reflects the frustration of early computer users with hardware reliability.

quotes.content: Real artists ship.
quotes.notes: Said to the Mac team during development. Emphasizes completing and releasing products over endless perfectionism.

quotes.content: Failure is an option here. If things are not failing, you are not innovating enough.
quotes.notes: Musk's philosophy on innovation at SpaceX. Contrasts with NASA's 'failure is not an option' Apollo 13 motto.

quotes.content: The web is more a social creation than a technical one. I designed it for a social effect.
quotes.notes: From Berners-Lee's book about creating the World Wide Web. Emphasizes the web's purpose for human connection.

quotes.content: A computer lets you make more mistakes faster than any other invention with the possible exceptions of handguns and Tequila.
quotes.notes: Humorous observation from tech journalist Mitch Ratcliffe about the double-edged nature of computing speed.

quotes.content: One machine can do the work of fifty ordinary men. No machine can do the work of one extraordinary man.
quotes.notes: From Hubbard's collection of sayings. Though from 1911, it anticipates debates about automation and human creativity.

quotes.content: The question of whether a computer can think is no more interesting than the question of whether a submarine can swim.
quotes.notes: From computer scientist Dijkstra's papers. Challenges the framing of AI debates with an analogy.

quotes.content: We are stuck with technology when what we really want is just stuff that works.
quotes.notes: From Adams' posthumously published collection. The Hitchhiker's Guide author was also a technology enthusiast and commentator.
